# Please provide details of the computing resources that were used to train models and make predictions.
# Please specify compute time for training models and querying separately for empirical prediction methods.
# Provide a detailed description of the hardware used to run the simulations.
# The 'Computing and hardware:' keyword is required as shown here.
All simulations were performed on the Pitzer Cluster at the Ohio Supercomputer Center
The reported compute time is taken as the walltime times the number of processors (core hours).
Pitzer has a mix of processors. We did not specify the processor type upon submission
The original Pitzer cluster was installed in late 2018 and

column2: Intel Xeon Skylake processor-based supercomputer with 260 nodes.
OSC installed an additional 398 Intel Xeon Cascade Lake processor-based

column1: nodes as part of a Pitzer Expansion cluster.

column2: note that no additional calculations were required beyond the pKa predictions.

# Important: Please do not use phrases which are identical to the section headers of logD data. For example do not use "Octanol-water predictions:"
# but use "Octanol-water predictions" instead (without the colon) or any other form. See example below.
Starting with the initial structures provided by the SAMPL8 organizers for each microstate
column2: geometries were first optimized with the PM7 method.

column1: The geometries were then further optimized at the B3LYP/def2-TZVP level of theory/basis set
A single point energy calculation was then performed to computed CM5 charges. The final structure and CM5 charges were used to predict
hydration free energies using the uESE method (DOI: 10.1002/jcc.26531) using code provided by the authors of the uESE manuscript.
The gas phase total free energy of each microstate was computed from the frequency calculation.
The relative free energies in water were computed from this information based on the proton dissociation reaction.
All of the electronic structure calculations were perfomed with Gaussian 16.
Using the results of the previous single point energy calculation for microstate 0 (the neutral reference) for each molecule
we used the uESE method to predict solvation free energies in water and the desired organic solvents. Assuming pure solvents
these values were then used to predict logP. Our logP values were corrected using our reaction free energies in water to

column2: where we assumed in the organic phase only the neutral reference molecule is present.

column1: Note that in the calculation of the solvation free energy in TBME
column2: uESE was not optimized for TBME. Here we adopt the solvent

column1: shift and solvent class (D) from diethyl ether
column2: and use the experimental dielectric constant for TBME.

column1: No additional calculations were necessary beyond that needed for the pKa predictions.
This submission includes the extra microstates provided by the challenge organizers.
